question: Should people visit the Yasukuni Shrine?

content.source_1: Yasukuni Shrine, “About Yasukuni Shrine” — Official site - Presents the shrine’s stated purpose as a place to commemorate Japan’s war dead and pray for peace, framing visits as acts of remembrance rather than political endorsement.
content.source_2: Japan-Guide.com, “Yasukuni Shrine (Tokyo)” — Travel guide - Provides practical visitor information and notes that the adjacent Yushukan museum presents a nationalist-leaning narrative of Japan’s wars, signaling that tourists may encounter contested interpretations of history.
content.source_3: Reuters, “Japan’s Abe visits Yasukuni Shrine, angering China and South Korea” (Dec. 26, 2013) - Reports that then–Prime Minister Shinzo Abe defended his visit as paying respects and praying for peace, not glorifying war—an argument often used by Japanese conservatives to justify visits.
content.source_4: Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People’s Republic of China, Spokesperson’s Remarks on Japanese leaders’ visits to Yasukuni (multiple statements) - Condemns such visits as honoring Class-A war criminals and hurting victims of Japanese aggression, arguing that visits undermine regional trust and historical reconciliation.
content.source_5: The Japan Times, “Court rules Koizumi’s Yasukuni visits unconstitutional” (Apr. 8, 2004) - Covers a Fukuoka District Court ruling that an official’s Yasukuni visit violated Japan’s constitutional separation of religion and state, highlighting domestic legal concerns over official (as opposed to private) visits.
